choices.text: Superomedial aspect of thigh and external genitalia

questions.text: During orthopedic surgery involving the adductor canal, a sensory nerve accompanying the femoral artery was inadvertently damaged. Post-operatively, the patient complains of numbness. Which of the following areas would most likely show sensory loss due to the injury?
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

The saphenous nerve, a purely sensory branch of the femoral nerve running in the adductor canal, supplies the medial leg and medial foot-so damage to it results in sensory loss in that region.

  • The saphenous nerve accompanies the femoral artery in the adductor canal but exits the canal before the adductor hiatus, emerging between sartorius and gracilis.
  • It then travels subcutaneously to supply:
    • Medial aspect of the leg
    • Medial border of foot up to the base of the great toe
  • Because it is sensory only, damage causes numbness/tingling without any motor weakness.

Explanation of other options:

Anterior thigh (Option A): Supplied by anterior cutaneous branches of the femoral nerve, which branch off above the adductor canal and are not affected in this case.

Posterior leg and lateral foot (Option C): Innervated by the sural nerve, formed by the medial sural cutaneous nerve (from tibial nerve) and communicating branch from common fibular nerve; this area is unrelated to adductor canal contents.

Superomedial aspect of thigh and external genitalia (Option D): Supplied by the ilioinguinal nerve, which originates from L1 and does not enter the adductor canal.

questions.text: Fracture of the femoral neck may lead to avascular necrosis of the femoral head due to the interruption of which artery?
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

B is the medial circumflex femoral artery, the primary blood supply to the femoral head. Fracture of the neck can disrupt this artery, leading to avascular necrosis.

  • The medial circumflex femoral artery (marked as B) arises from the profunda femoris artery (or directly from the femoral artery in some individuals) and wraps posteriorly around the femur to reach the posterior aspect of the femoral neck.
  • It gives rise to retinacular branches that pass along the femoral neck within the synovial folds to supply the femoral head.
  • In femoral neck fractures, these vessels can be torn, compromising the blood supply to the femoral head and leading to avascular necrosis (AVN).
  • The lateral circumflex femoral artery (A) also contributes, especially in young individuals, but its contribution is much less significant in adults.
  • Clinical Insight:
    • In displaced femoral neck fractures, especially in the elderly, hip replacement is often considered over fixation due to the risk of AVN from medial circumflex artery disruption.

Blood Supply of the Femoral Head

  • Medial Circumflex Femoral Artery (MCFA)
    • Primary and most important source in adults.
    • Arises from the profunda femoris artery or directly from the femoral artery.
    • It travels posteriorly around the femoral neck and gives retinacular arteries (posterior superior and posterior inferior branches) that ascend within the synovial folds of the joint capsule.
    • These retinacular arteries pierce the capsule and enter the femoral head via the neck, supplying most of the weight-bearing zone.
    • Clinical Note: Damage to the MCFA during femoral neck fracture can lead to avascular necrosis (AVN) of the femoral head.
  • Lateral Circumflex Femoral Artery (LCFA)
    • Arises from profunda femoris artery.
    • Runs anteriorly and gives ascending, transverse, and descending branches.
    • The ascending branch contributes minimally to the femoral head blood supply via anterior retinacular branches, especially in children.
    • In adults, its contribution is minor, often insufficient alone to maintain femoral head viability after fracture.
  • Artery of the Ligamentum Teres (Foveal artery)
    • Branch of the obturator artery (or sometimes medial circumflex femoral artery).
    • Travels within the ligament of the head of femur.
    • Supplies only a small central area of the femoral head (fovea capitis).
    • Insignificant in adults, but important in children before epiphyseal fusion.

questions.text: In the middle third of the thigh, the superficial and deep femoral arteries are separated by:
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

In the middle third of the thigh, the adductor longus lies between the superficial femoral artery (anteriorly) and the deep femoral artery (posteriorly), acting as a separating muscular plane.

  • In the femoral triangle and upper thigh, the femoral artery (also called the superficial femoral artery when distinguishing it from the profunda) gives rise to the deep femoral artery (profunda femoris).
  • The deep femoral artery dives posteriorly and medially to lie deep to the adductor longus muscle.
  • Meanwhile, the superficial femoral artery continues more anteriorly and medially, eventually entering the adductor canal.
  • Thus, in the middle third of the thigh, the adductor longus lies in between the two vessels and anatomically separates them.

Explanation of other options:

Adductor magnus (Option B): Lies posterior to both arteries; involved in forming the floor of the adductor canal and doesn't separate the arteries directly.

Gracilis (Option C): Lies more medially in the thigh; doesn't intervene between the superficial and deep femoral arteries.

Pectineus (Option D): Lies in the upper part of the femoral triangle, above the region where the arteries separate; not involved in their middle-third relationship.

questions.text: Identify the type of gait in the given image. Which is the likely nerve involved in this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

The gait shown is a scissor gait, commonly associated with spastic cerebral palsy, and the nerve marked as 2 (Obturator nerve) is most likely involved due to its motor supply to the thigh adductors.

  • The first image depicts a scissor gait, characterized by:
    • Thighs crossing over each other in a scissor-like pattern while walking.
    • Often associated with bilateral spasticity, especially of the hip adductors.
    • The most common cause is bilateral upper motor neuron lesions, such as in cerebral palsy.
  • The obturator nerve (marked as 2 in the second image) innervates the adductor muscles of the thigh (adductor longus, brevis, magnus, and gracilis), which become hypertonic in spastic cerebral palsy, contributing to this gait abnormality.
  • The femoral nerve innervates the quadriceps muscles, which extend the leg at the knee.
  • The inferior gluteal nerve innervates gluteus maximus, which is important for powerful extension of the thigh.
  • The tibial nerve innervates the hamstrings, which flex the knee and extend the thigh.
    • The tibial nerve also innervates the muscles of the posterior compartment of the leg, which plantar flexes the foot.

questions.text: After suffering a penetrating injury in the left femoral triangle, a patient was unable to walk normally because her left knee collapsed into flexion upon weight bearing. The nerve to which muscle was damaged?
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

Quadriceps femoris extends the knee, and its paralysis leads to knee buckling upon weight-bearing.

  • The quadriceps femoris muscle is the primary extensor of the knee joint, innervated by the femoral nerve.
  • It is located in the anterior compartment of the thigh, and its four parts include rectus femoris, vastus lateralis, vastus medialis, and vastus intermedius.
  • A penetrating injury in the femoral triangle can damage the femoral nerve, leading to:
    • Weakness or paralysis of the quadriceps
    • Inability to extend the knee
    • Knee collapsing or giving way during weight-bearing, as the patient cannot maintain knee extension
  • This is a classic presentation of femoral nerve injury affecting quadriceps function.

Explanation of other options:

Biceps femoris (Option A): Supplied by the sciatic nerve; involved in knee flexion, not extension.

Gluteus Maximus (Option C): Supplied by the inferior gluteal nerve; functions in hip extension and not related to knee stability.

Gluteus minimus (Option D): Supplied by the superior gluteal nerve; functions in hip abduction and stabilization, not knee extension.

questions.text:
Read the following statements regarding the femoral triangle:
1. The lateral boundary of the femoral triangle is formed by the sartorius muscle.
2. The floor is formed by pectineus medially and iliopsoas laterally.
3. The femoral nerve lies medially to the femoral vein.
4. The roof of the femoral triangle is formed by fascia lata and skin.
Which of the above statements are correct?
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

The femoral nerve lies lateral to the artery and vein in the triangle, not medial, which makes statement 3 incorrect.

Femoral Triangle

  • The femoral triangle is a subfascial space in the anterior thigh, bounded:
    • Laterally by the medial border of sartorius,
    • Medially by the medial border of adductor longus,
    • Superiorly (base) by the inguinal ligament.
  • The floor is formed by iliopsoas (laterally) and pectineus (medially).
  • The roof is composed of fascia lata, superficial fascia, and skin.
  • Contents (from lateral to medial):
    • Femoral Nerve - Artery - Vein - Lymphatics (mnemonic: NAVeL).
  • So, the femoral nerve is lateral to the vein, not medial.

questions.text: Inability to extend the knee and loss of cutaneous sensation over the anterior surface of the thigh would indicate a lesion or compression of the:
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

The femoral nerve supplies the quadriceps femoris (knee extension) and provides cutaneous sensation to the anterior thigh.

  • The femoral nerve (L2-L4) arises from the lumbar plexus and passes beneath the inguinal ligament to enter the femoral triangle.
  • It supplies the anterior compartment of the thigh, especially:
    • Quadriceps femoris → responsible for knee extension
    • Sartorius and pectineus (partial innervation)
  • It also gives rise to anterior cutaneous branches for the skin of the anterior thigh and the saphenous nerve for the medial leg.
  • Thus, inability to extend the knee (due to quadriceps paralysis) and sensory loss over the anterior thigh both strongly point to femoral nerve injury.

Explanation of other options:

Obturator nerve (Option A): Supplies medial thigh muscles (adductors); no role in knee extension or anterior thigh sensation.

Tibial nerve (Option B): Supplies posterior thigh and leg muscles; responsible for plantarflexion, not knee extension or anterior thigh sensation.

Lateral femoral cutaneous nerve (Option D): Only provides sensory innervation to the lateral thigh; does not control motor function or anterior thigh sensation.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT located within the adductor canal?
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

The deep femoral artery does not pass through the adductor canal, whereas the others are key structures within it.

  • The adductor canal (Hunter's canal) is an intramuscular passage in the middle third of the thigh that allows structures to pass from the femoral triangle to the popliteal fossa.
    • Contents of the adductor canal include:
      • Femoral artery
      • Femoral vein
      • Saphenous nerve (sensory) (Option A ruled out)
      • Nerve to vastus medialis (Option C ruled out)
      • Descending genicular artery and nerve (Option B ruled out)
  • The deep femoral artery (profunda femoris) arises proximally from the femoral artery in the femoral triangle, and it remains deep and posterior, not entering the adductor canal.

questions.text: During a surgical procedure in which the lower abdominal wall has been opened, the retractor blades damaged a nerve lying between the iliacus and psoas major muscles. The patient has weakened hip flexion and an inability to extend the knee, as well as analgesia on the anterior thigh and medial leg. What nerve has been compressed?
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

The femoral nerve runs between the psoas major and iliacus muscles and supplies the hip flexors, knee extensors, and sensory innervation to the anterior thigh and medial leg.

  • The femoral nerve arises from the posterior divisions of the L2-L4 spinal nerves and descends through the psoas major, emerging on its lateral border.
  • It travels between psoas major and iliacus, then passes under the inguinal ligament into the thigh.
  • Motor functions:
    • Supplies iliacus, part of pectineus, and quadriceps femoris, contributing to hip flexion and knee extension.
  • Sensory functions:
    • Supplies the anterior thigh via anterior cutaneous branches.
    • Supplies the medial leg and foot via the saphenous nerve.
  • Compression or injury where the femoral nerve lies between iliacus and psoas major leads to:
    • Weak hip flexion (iliacus involvement)
    • Inability to extend knee (quadriceps involvement)
    • Loss of sensation in the anterior thigh and medial leg (via saphenous nerve)

Explanation of other options:

A - Genitofemoral nerve (Option B): Supplies skin of scrotum/labia and femoral triangle area, not motor to hip/knee; lies on the anterior surface of psoas, not between psoas and iliacus.

D - Obturator nerve (Option C): Travels medially along the pelvic wall; supplies adductor muscles and medial thigh sensation, not involved in knee extension or anterior thigh sensation.

C - Lumbosacral trunks (Option D): Formed by part of L4 and all of L5 joining the sacral plexus; involved in posterior thigh and lower leg, not anterior thigh.

questions.text: A female patient complains of pain in her groin region that increases with coughing. An MRI reveals a loop of ilium passing inferiorly, posterior to the superior pubic ramus. What type of hernia is this?
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

The hernia passes inferior and posterior to the superior pubic ramus, consistent with the location of an obturator hernia.

  • An obturator hernia is a rare type of abdominal hernia where a loop of bowel protrudes through the obturator canal, a small opening in the pelvic bone formed by the obturator foramen and membrane.
  • This canal transmits the obturator nerve and vessels to the medial thigh.
  • Key clinical features include:
    • Groin pain that worsens with thigh movement or coughing.
    • Pain may radiate to the medial thigh due to compression of the obturator nerve (Howship-Romberg sign).
  • Often occurs in elderly, thin, multiparous women.
  • On MRI or CT:
    • The herniated loop of bowel is seen posterior to the superior pubic ramus and medial to the femoral vessels, hallmark of an obturator hernia.

Explanation of other options:

Femoral (Option B): Herniates below and lateral to the pubic tubercle, through the femoral canal, anterior to the superior pubic ramus-not posterior.

Direct inguinal (Option C): Protrudes medially to the inferior epigastric vessels through Hesselbach's triangle-located above the inguinal ligament, not near the obturator canal.

Indirect inguinal (Option D): Enters the deep inguinal ring, lateral to the inferior epigastric vessels, above and lateral to pubic tubercle, not posterior or inferior to the superior pubic ramus.

questions.text: Childhood immunizations are sometimes given via intramuscular injections into the quadriceps muscles of the anterior thigh. At the mid-thigh level, a needle passing into the space deep to the sartorius muscle might pierce the femoral vessels as they lie in the:
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

At mid-thigh level, the femoral vessels lie deep to the sartorius muscle within the adductor canal.

  • The adductor canal (also called the subsartorial canal or Hunter's canal) is an intramuscular passageway located in the middle third of the thigh.
  • It serves as a conduit for neurovascular structures traveling from the femoral triangle toward the popliteal fossa.
  • Boundaries:
    • Roof: Sartorius muscle
    • Medial wall: Adductor longus and magnus
    • Lateral wall: Vastus medialis
  • Contents:
    • Femoral artery and vein
    • Saphenous nerve
    • Nerve to vastus medialis
  • A needle inserted deeply in this area (beneath the sartorius at mid-thigh) risks piercing the femoral artery and vein in the adductor canal.

Explanation of other options:

Adductor hiatus (Option B): A gap in the adductor magnus near the knee, where femoral vessels pass into the popliteal fossa-not at mid-thigh.

Adductor triangle (Option C): Not an anatomical structure; likely a misnomer or confusion with the femoral triangle, which lies proximal to mid-thigh.

Femoral canal (Option D): A small compartment medial to the femoral vein in the femoral triangle, housing lymphatics-not located at mid-thigh.

questions.text: An obturator hernia that compresses the obturator nerve in the obturator canal may affect the function of all of the following muscles EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

Pectineus is a muscle of the medial compartment of the thigh. Marked as B in the image.

  • Most of the muscles in this compartment are adductors and medial rotators, innervated by the obturator nerve.
  • However, pectineus is the exception of the medial compartment, it's innervated by the femoral nerve, and it's a hip flexor.
  • So, damage to the obturator nerve would not affect pectineus!
  • Adductor brevis, adductor longus, and gracilis are muscles of the medial compartment which adduct and medially rotate the thigh, they are all innervated by the obturator nerve.
  • The obturator externus is also innervated by the obturator nerve; it is a lateral rotator found in the medial compartment of the thigh.

questions.text: A patient with a tuberculous abscess (localized collection of pus) on the iliopsoas muscle in the femoral triangle presented impaired flexion of the thigh and extension of the leg. Which of the following nerves was likely involved?
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

Involvement of the femoral nerve, which passes through the iliopsoas groove and the femoral triangle, explains impaired thigh flexion and leg extension.

  • The femoral nerve (L2-L4) is the major motor and sensory nerve of the anterior compartment of the thigh.
  • It emerges between the iliacus and psoas major muscles and enters the femoral triangle, just lateral to the femoral artery.
  • It supplies:
    • Iliacus and pectineus (help in hip flexion)
    • Quadriceps femoris (primary extensor of the knee)
  • A tuberculous iliopsoas abscess may compress or irritate the femoral nerve, especially where it lies in the iliopsoas groove or femoral triangle, leading to:
    • Weak hip flexion (due to iliacus involvement)
    • Weak knee extension (due to quadriceps involvement)
    • Possibly reduced patellar reflex

Explanation of other options:

Inferior gluteal (Option B): Innervates gluteus maximus, involved in hip extension, not thigh flexion or leg extension.

Obturator (Option C): Supplies medial thigh (adductors), does not control hip flexion or knee extension.

Sciatic (Option D): Innervates posterior thigh muscles and most of the leg and foot, but does not enter the femoral triangle or directly affect hip flexion/knee extension.

questions.text: A serious complication of fractures of the femoral neck is avascular necrosis of the femoral head. This usually results from rupture of which artery?
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

The medial circumflex femoral artery is the primary blood supply to the femoral head, and its rupture during femoral neck fractures leads to avascular necrosis.

  • The femoral head receives blood from multiple sources, but the most critical contributor in adults is the medial circumflex femoral artery, a branch of the profunda femoris (deep femoral) artery.
  • This artery courses posterior to the femoral neck and supplies the retinacular arteries, which ascend along the femoral neck to reach the head.
  • In intracapsular fractures (such as subcapital femoral neck fractures), these vessels are frequently torn, cutting off the main blood supply to the femoral head and resulting in avascular necrosis (AVN).
  • The acetabular branch of the obturator artery (via the ligamentum teres) contributes minimally in adults and is insufficient to prevent AVN on its own.

choices.text: Above the middle of the inguinal ligament
Lateral to the femoral arterial pulse
Medial to the femoral arterial pulse

questions.text: At which site could one expect to enter the femoral vein with a simple percutaneous (through the skin) introduction of an instrument?
questions.solution:
Explanation of the answer:

The femoral vein lies medially to the femoral artery just below the inguinal ligament, making it the correct site for percutaneous access.

  • In the femoral triangle, the contents from lateral to media are: (can be remembered by the mnemonic "NAVeL")
    • N - Femoral Nerve
    • A - Femoral Artery
    • V - Femoral Vein
    • L - Lymphatics
  • The femoral vein lies immediately medial to the femoral artery and is a common site for central venous access, cardiac catheterization, and other vascular interventions.
  • It lies within the femoral sheath, just inferior to the inguinal ligament.
  • By palpating the femoral arterial pulse, a clinician can reliably identify the femoral vein by inserting the instrument medial to the pulse.

Explanation of other options:

Above the middle of the inguinal ligament (Option A): This is outside the femoral triangle and would risk entering the abdominal cavity, not the femoral vein.

Lateral to the femoral arterial pulse (Option B): This would lead to puncture of the femoral nerve, which lies lateral to the artery, not ideal and dangerous.

Lateral to the pubic tubercle (Option C): This is an anatomically vague and inaccurate description, not a reliable landmark for vein cannulation.

choices.text: Descending branch of the lateral circumflex femoral
First perforating branch of the deep femoral

questions.text: If the femoral artery is occluded at the beginning of the adductor canal, which artery could help provide viability to the leg through collateral circulation?
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

The descending branch of the lateral circumflex femoral artery anastomoses with both the descending genicular branch of the femoral artery as well as the lateral superior genicular branch of the popliteal artery.

  • These connections provide collateral circulation to the knee and leg.
  • The descending genicular artery branches from the femoral artery just superior to the adductor hiatus.
  • If the femoral artery was occluded, this artery would not receive blood flow.
  • The perforating branches of the deep femoral artery provide blood to the posterior thigh.
  • The medial circumflex femoral artery is a branch of the femoral that supplies blood to the medial thigh and hip.
  • The obturator artery is a branch of the anterior division of the internal iliac which supplies the medial thigh and hip.
  • None of these arteries would be involved in any anastomoses with the leg.

questions.text: The pulse of the femoral artery is best felt at which superficial reference point?
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

The femoral artery pulse is most reliably palpated within the femoral triangle, just below the inguinal ligament.

  • It lies between the femoral nerve on its lateral side and the femoral vein on its medial side.
  • This is where you would take the femoral pulse.
  • Anterior to the ankle joint, you can feel for the pulse of the dorsalis pedis artery.
  • In the popliteal fossa, you can feel for the pulse of the popliteal artery. (Although, this can be somewhat difficult since the popliteal artery is deep to the popliteal nerve and vein.)

Femoral Triangle

  • The femoral triangle is a subfascial space located in the anterior thigh.
  • It is bounded by:
    • Superiorly - Inguinal ligament
    • Laterally - Sartorius muscle
    • Medially - Adductor longus muscle
  • The floor is formed by the iliopsoas and pectineus muscles, and the femoral artery lies within the triangle, medial to the femoral nerve and lateral to the femoral vein.
  • The femoral pulse can be felt by pressing the artery against the underlying pectineus or femoral head, approximately 2-3 cm below the midpoint of the inguinal ligament, which places it within the femoral triangle.

Explanation of other options:

Mid inguinal point (Option A): Anatomically refers to the midpoint between the ASIS and pubic symphysis, where the femoral artery enters the triangle, but it's not the most reliable place to palpate the pulse.

Midpoint of inguinal ligament (Option C): This is the entry point of the femoral artery beneath the ligament, not ideal for pulse palpation as the artery is still partially deep.

Popliteal fossa (Option D): This is the site for the popliteal artery pulse, not the femoral artery.

questions.text: Match the following muscles with their primary actions at the hip joint:
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

  1. Gluteus medius → (B) Abduction; It is the primary abductor of the hip joint and stabilizes the pelvis during walking.
  2. Iliopsoas → (C) Flexion; Iliopsoas (iliacus + psoas major) is the main flexor of the hip joint, especially active during walking and stair climbing.
  3. Adductor longus → (D) Adduction; It pulls the thigh toward the midline.
  4. Gluteus maximus → (A) Extension; The strongest extensor of the hip, especially active during rising from sitting, running, and climbing.

questions.text: An elderly woman was found to have a hernial sac in the right femoral triangle and a marked weakness in adduction at the right hip joint. Which nerve was likely compressed by this herniation?
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

The obturator nerve, which innervates the adductor muscles, runs close to the femoral triangle and can be compressed by a femoral hernia, leading to weakness in thigh adduction.

  • The femoral triangle is bordered by the inguinal ligament (superiorly), sartorius (laterally), and adductor longus (medially).
  • A femoral hernia occurs inferior to the inguinal ligament, where the femoral canal allows protrusion of abdominal contents.
  • The obturator nerve arises from the lumbar plexus (L2-L4) and passes through the obturator canal to supply the medial compartment of the thigh, including:
    • Adductor longus
    • Adductor brevis
    • Adductor magnus (adductor part)
    • Gracilis
    • Obturator externus
  • Compression or entrapment of the obturator nerve (e.g., by a femoral hernia) can cause:
    • Weakness in adduction of the thigh
    • Medial thigh pain or sensory loss

Explanation of other options:

Femoral (Option A): Supplies the anterior compartment of the thigh (e.g., quadriceps); injury causes weakness in hip flexion and knee extension, not adduction.

Inferior gluteal (Option B): Innervates gluteus maximus, a hip extensor, not involved in adduction.

Pudendal (Option D): Supplies perineal structures, not the thigh; unrelated to hip adduction.

questions.text: Which of the following pass deep to inguinal ligament?
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

The round ligament of the uterus passes through the deep inguinal ring, travels within the inguinal canal, and exits at the superficial inguinal ring, passing deep to the inguinal ligament.

  • The inguinal ligament extends from the anterior superior iliac spine (ASIS) to the pubic tubercle.
  • Many structures pass deep to it via the retro-inguinal space, including neurovascular and muscular elements.
  • The round ligament of the uterus, a remnant of the gubernaculum, passes through the inguinal canal, beginning deep to the inguinal ligament at the deep inguinal ring.
  • It travels anteriorly and inserts into the labia majora, helping maintain the anteverted position of the uterus.

Explanation of other options:

Femoral nerve (Option A): Passes deep to the inguinal ligament, but lateral to the femoral artery, this is a true statement, making it an incorrect answer only because the question asked for the one that passes specifically through the inguinal canal like the round ligament.

Femoral vein (Option B): Also passes deep to the inguinal ligament, within the femoral sheath, but does not pass through the inguinal canal.

Psoas major muscle (Option C): Passes deep to the inguinal ligament, but does so lateral to the femoral nerve, not through the inguinal canal.

Key Takeaways:

Only the round ligament of the uterus (and the spermatic cord in males) passes through the inguinal canal

questions.text: Which movement would fail in case of paralysis of the quadriceps femoris muscle?
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

The quadriceps femoris is the primary extensor of the knee joint, so its paralysis would prevent knee extension.

  • The quadriceps femoris muscle, innervated by the femoral nerve (L2-L4), is the major extensor of the leg at the knee joint.
  • It has four parts:
    • Rectus femoris (also assists in hip flexion)
    • Vastus lateralis
    • Vastus medialis
    • Vastus intermedius
  • When this muscle group is paralyzed:
    • The knee cannot be extended, making standing, walking, or rising from a seated position difficult.
    • The patellar reflex is also absent, as it depends on the integrity of the femoral nerve and quadriceps.

Explanation of other options:

Adduction at the hip (Option A): Performed by adductor muscles (adductor longus, brevis, magnus), innervated by the obturator nerve, not by quadriceps.

Extension at the hip (Option B): Controlled mainly by gluteus maximus, innervated by the inferior gluteal nerve, not the quadriceps.

Flexion at the knee (Option D): Performed by hamstrings (biceps femoris, semitendinosus, semimembranosus), innervated by the sciatic nerve, not the quadriceps.

questions.text:
Read the following statements about the femoral canal and femoral hernia:
1. The femoral canal lies lateral to the femoral vein within the femoral sheath.
2. The femoral ring is the abdominal opening of the femoral canal and is a potential site for femoral hernia, especially in females.
3. The lacunar ligament forms the medial boundary of the femoral ring.
4. A femoral hernia typically presents above the inguinal ligament and medial to the pubic tubercle.
Which of the above statements is/are incorrect?
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

Statement 1 and 4 are incorrect because the femoral canal lies medial to the femoral vein, and femoral hernias appear below the inguinal ligament.

  • The femoral canal is the medial compartment of the femoral sheath, and it contains lymphatics and fat.
  • Its boundaries at the femoral ring:
    • Anterior: Inguinal ligament
    • Medial: Lacunar ligament
    • Posterior: Pectineal ligament
    • Lateral: Femoral vein
  • Femoral hernias:
    • Are more common in females due to a wider pelvis.
    • Emerge below the inguinal ligament, medial to the femoral vein, and can protrude through the saphenous opening.

questions.text: A 63-year-old female patient says that she has pain in her groin and upper thigh. Upon examination, you palpate a lump located below the inguinal ligament lateral to its attachment to the pubic tubercle. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

A lump below the inguinal ligament and lateral to the pubic tubercle is characteristic of a femoral hernia.

  • A femoral hernia occurs when abdominal contents protrude through the femoral canal, which is located below the inguinal ligament, medial to the femoral vein, and lateral to the pubic tubercle.
  • Femoral hernias are more common in females, especially elderly women, due to a wider pelvis and a larger femoral canal.
  • The patient's pain in the groin and upper thigh and the position of the lump suggest that the herniation occurred in the femoral canal.
  • These hernias have a high risk of strangulation, making early diagnosis and treatment important.

Explanation of other options:

Direct inguinal hernia (Option A): Occurs medial to the inferior epigastric vessels, through Hesselbach's triangle, and presents above the inguinal ligament, not below.

Indirect inguinal hernia (Option B): Passes lateral to the inferior epigastric vessels through the deep inguinal ring, and also presents above the inguinal ligament.

Obturator hernia (Option D): Very rare and usually presents with referred pain along the medial thigh (Howship-Romberg sign) but is not palpable as a lump in the groin.

questions.text: Varicosities in the subcutaneous veins of the medial thigh were observed at physical examination. The vein involved was most likely the:
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

Varicosities on the medial aspect of the thigh most commonly involve the greater saphenous vein, the longest superficial vein in the body.

  • The greater saphenous vein arises from the medial side of the dorsal venous arch of the foot, runs anterior to the medial malleolus, ascends along the medial side of the leg and thigh, and drains into the femoral vein at the saphenous opening in the upper thigh.
  • It is commonly affected by varicosities due to the incompetence of its valves, especially where it joins the femoral vein.
  • Being superficial and subcutaneous, it is easily visible and prone to varicosities, especially in conditions with venous stasis or prolonged standing.

Explanation of other options:

Femoral vein (Option A): A deep vein, not subcutaneous; not typically involved in visible varicosities.

Lesser saphenous vein (Option C): Drains the posterior aspect of the leg, not the medial thigh.

Popliteal vein (Option D): A deep vein located in the popliteal fossa behind the knee; not involved in superficial medial thigh varicosities.

choices.text: In the deep venous system of the thigh

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman presents to the clinic with visibly dilated, tortuous veins along the medial aspect of her lower limb, which worsen on prolonged standing. The attending physician suspects varicose veins involving the great saphenous system. He asks you where the valves are most likely incompetent, leading to this condition. What is your most accurate response?
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

Incompetence of the valve at the saphenofemoral junction causes retrograde flow from the femoral vein into the great saphenous vein, resulting in varicosities.

  • The great saphenous vein (GSV) drains into the femoral vein at the saphenofemoral junction near the femoral triangle, just below the inguinal ligament.
  • This junction contains a valve that prevents retrograde blood flow.
  • When the valves at this junction become incompetent, blood flows backwards into the GSV.
  • This retrograde pressure leads to distension and tortuosity of the superficial veins, classic varicose veins.
  • These valves are particularly vulnerable due to gravity-dependent hydrostatic pressure and standing for prolonged periods.

Explanation of other options:

Femoral vein (Option A): This is a deep vein, and although it connects to the GSV, its valves are not the primary cause of superficial varicosities.

Deep venous system of the thigh (Option C): Incompetence here would cause deep vein issues, such as DVT, not superficial varicose veins.

Popliteal-small saphenous junction (Option D): Incompetence here leads to varicosities in the posterior leg, not the medial thigh/leg, which is affected in GSV varicosities.

choices.text: The great saphenous vein runs posterior to the lateral malleolus and drains into the popliteal vein.
The small saphenous vein ascends along the medial side of the leg and drains into the femoral vein.
The great saphenous vein ascends anterior to the medial malleolus and drains into the femoral vein at the saphenofemoral junction.
The small saphenous vein runs along the medial side of the leg and drains into the posterior tibial vein.

questions.text: Four statements are given below regarding the course and drainage of the great and small saphenous veins. Identify the correct statement:
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

The great saphenous vein ascends on the medial side, passing anterior to the medial malleolus, and enters the femoral vein in the femoral triangle.

  • Great saphenous vein begins from the medial end of the dorsal venous arch, ascends anterior to the medial malleolus, passes posterior to the medial condyle of the femur, and then continues superiorly along the medial thigh, piercing the cribriform fascia to drain into the femoral vein at the saphenofemoral junction.
  • The small saphenous vein begins at the lateral end of the dorsal venous arch, ascends posterior to the lateral malleolus, then courses up the midline of the posterior leg, and drains into the popliteal vein in the popliteal fossa.

questions.text:
A construction worker, who wears a heavy tool belt tightly around his waist throughout the day, complains of tingling and numbness over the anterolateral surface of his thigh, especially after long shifts. There are no motor deficits.
Which of the following nerves is most likely compressed?
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

Compression of the lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh under the inguinal ligament leads to paresthesia over the anterolateral thigh, a condition known as meralgia paresthetica.

  • The lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh is a purely sensory nerve that arises from L2-L3 of the lumbar plexus.
  • It travels under the inguinal ligament, near the anterior superior iliac spine (ASIS), to supply the anterolateral skin of the thigh.
  • Tight belts, obesity, pregnancy, or prolonged hip flexion can compress this nerve, leading to meralgia paresthetica.
    • Causes burning, tingling, or numbness in the distribution area.
  • Motor function remains intact because the nerve is only sensory.

Explanation of other options:

Femoral nerve (Option A): This nerve supplies motor innervation to the anterior compartment of the thigh and sensory innervation to the anterior thigh and medial leg. Injury would also cause motor weakness, not just isolated anterolateral thigh paresthesia.

Ilioinguinal nerve (Option B): This nerve supplies the skin of the superomedial thigh, base of the penis or mons pubis, and anterior scrotum or labia majora. It does not innervate the anterolateral thigh.

Obturator nerve (Option D): This nerve innervates the medial thigh muscles (adductors) and provides cutaneous sensation to the medial thigh, not the anterolateral thigh.

questions.text: A patient with a diabetic ulcer in the anterior midline of the ankle region experienced loss of cutaneous sensation on the dorsal surface of the foot. Which nerve was most likely damaged?
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

The superficial fibular nerve supplies cutaneous sensation to the dorsum of the foot, except for the first web space.

  • The superficial fibular (peroneal) nerve, a branch of the common fibular nerve, emerges from the lateral compartment of the leg and becomes superficial in the lower third of the leg.
  • It provides motor innervation to the fibularis longus and brevis muscles (which evert the foot) and cutaneous sensation to most of the dorsum of the foot and the anterolateral lower leg.
  • In this case, the ulcer at the anterior ankle region would put the superficial fibular nerve at risk as it pierces the deep fascia to become superficial in this very region.

Explanation of other options:

Femoral (Option A): The femoral nerve supplies the anterior thigh muscles and the medial leg via the saphenous branch; it does not innervate the dorsum of the foot.

Lateral sural cutaneous (Option B): This nerve arises from the common fibular nerve and supplies only the proximal lateral leg, not the dorsum of the foot.

Saphenous (Option C): A branch of the femoral nerve, the saphenous nerve provides cutaneous innervation to the medial leg and foot, but not the dorsum.

questions.text: Following a car accident in which the patient received a deep laceration on the medial side of his right knee, the patient notices numbness along the medial side of his right leg and foot. He has no motor deficit. The nerve which appears to have been injured is the:
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

The saphenous nerve, a sensory branch of the femoral nerve, supplies the medial side of the leg and foot and is vulnerable to injury near the medial knee.

  • The saphenous nerve is the terminal sensory branch of the femoral nerve.
  • After passing through the adductor canal, it becomes superficial at the medial side of the knee and descends along the medial leg and foot, providing cutaneous innervation.
  • In this case, the patient has:
    • A deep laceration over the medial knee
    • Numbness along the medial leg and foot
    • No motor deficits (as the saphenous nerve is purely sensory)
  • This constellation of findings points toward injury to the saphenous nerve.

Explanation of other options:

Femoral nerve (Option A): Supplies the anterior thigh muscles (motor) and gives rise to the saphenous nerve for sensory innervation. Damage to the main femoral nerve would cause motor deficits, which are absent here.

Sural nerve (Option C): Provides cutaneous innervation to the posterolateral leg and lateral foot, not the medial side.

Superficial fibular nerve (Option D): Supplies the anterolateral leg and most of the dorsum of the foot, not the medial side.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding the adductor canal is/are correct?
1. The adductor canal is located in the middle third of the thigh and lies deep to the sartorius muscle.
2. The saphenous nerve lies anterior to the femoral artery within the canal.
3. The nerve to vastus medialis enters the adductor canal and lies in its anterior wall.
4. The femoral artery exits the adductor canal through the adductor hiatus to become the popliteal artery.
Select the correct statements:
questions.solution:
The saphenous nerve lies lateral or anterior-lateral, not directly anterior, to the femoral artery within the adductor canal.

  • The adductor canal is an intramuscular passage in the middle third of the thigh bordered by:
    • Anteromedially: Sartorius muscle
    • Laterally: Vastus medialis
    • Posteriorly: Adductor longus and magnus
  • Contents:
    • Femoral artery and femoral vein
    • Saphenous nerve (sensory branch of femoral nerve)
    • Nerve to vastus medialis
    • Descending genicular artery
  • Placements:
    • The saphenous nerve lies lateral or anterolateral to the femoral artery (not strictly anterior).
    • The nerve to vastus medialis enters the canal and travels in the anterior wall.
    • The femoral artery exits via the adductor hiatus to become the popliteal artery.
